topic.title: HPE Helion 1.1 Development Platform: Commercial Installation and Configuration

body.p: The HPE Helion Development Platform currently contains four components: Application Lifecycle Service (ALS), Marketplace Service, Messaging Service and Database Service.
The following topics explain how to install and configure the HPE Helion Development Platform. There is also Troubleshooting documentation to handle issues that may occur.

li.xref: Installing the HPE Helion Development Platform

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: The HPE Helion Development Platform is installed in the overcloud of HPE Helion OpenStack

li.p: You must log in to the system where you intend to run the installation script as the root user.
The Cinder block storage service must be configured with either VSA or 3Par.
If you installed HPE Helion OpenStack with KVM hypervisor support, configure HP StoreVirtual VSA for Block Storage or configure HPE 3PAR StoreServ Storage.

The system running the installer needs to have Python 2.7. Most modern operating systems include this as part of their base toolkit. This document is geared toward a Linux operating system but this does not preclude the installer from running on other operating systems with some minor modifications to the command-line statements.
The installer requires the following packages. If they are not found, it will prompt you to install them.

section.title: Installing the HPE Helion Development Platform
Downloading and unpacking the installation file
section.p: The installation of the HPE Helion Development Platform for the HPE Helion OpenStack Commercial Edition is provided as a small compressed tar file. The images for the actual services will be downloaded at the installer's request.

p.note: Should you need more assistance during installation, the install script also has a help feature.

ol.li: Register at and download the package from the HPE Helion Development Platform (HDN).
Before you begin the installation, unpack the tar file.tar -zxvf DevelopmentPlatform_1.1.0.7.tar.gz
Navigate to the dev-platform-installer directory inside the dev-platform-installer folder.cd dev-platform-installer

If your network uses a proxy, it may be necessary to set the https_proxy shell variable so that the installer may download required Python libraries from the pypi site. To set the https_proxy shell variable, enter the following command:export https_proxy={ip address or url of http proxy}
Example:export https_proxy=http://proxy.example.com

Confirm that you have access to the pypi site. The following commands will verify access to the site and download one of the prerequisite files as a brief test.If ping is unavailable, use wget.ping pypi.python.org sudo -E pip install python-novaclient

If your network uses a proxy, you must define the proxy exclusion list so that proxies are not used for communicating with the services in the overcloud. To define the proxy exclusion list, enter the following command:export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,{ip address or host name of identity service aka keystone}
Example:export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,10.0.0.10

Validate Keystone access on port 5000 using curl.curl https://{ip address or host name of identity service aka keystone}:5000
Example:curl https://10.0.0.10:5000

Run this command to install the Helion Development Platform. You can run this command on any machine that can access the overcloud, but it is recommended that you run it on the seed node. By default the Username is admin and the Region is regionOne. Use the admin tenant_id from the overcloud. The parameter location/ephemeralca-cacert.crt can be found on the HPE Helion OpenStack seed VM at /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/ephemeralca-cacert.crt sudo ./DevelopmentPlatform_Setup.sh \ -p {admin_user_password} \ -a {auth_host_ip_address} \ -u {username} \ -i {tenant_id} \ -r {region_name} \ -e {location/ephemeralca-cacert.crt} \ install
Once the installation is complete, you should see output similar to the following:2014-06-17 16:53:19.765 INFO Install Complete

section.title: Install the Messaging Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the Messaging service from the Development Platform.

ol.li: Open Horizon and login as the "admin" user. Then click on the Admin panel in Horizon and select Development Platform. Finally, click Configure Services.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services screen and enter your username and password for the HPE Download Network (HPN). Select the Sign-up button if you do not have an account.

section.title: Download and Configure the Messaging Service

ol.li:
In the Configure Services panel locate the Messaging item in the Configure Services table and select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.
Downloading multiple services simultaneously is not supported, and will leave the server in an error state.
Once the download is complete, click the Configure Service button to configure the Messaging Service and wait for the configuration step to complete.
Log out from the Horizon dashboard. Log back into the Horizon dashboard as a non-admin user and click on the Messaging panel under the current Project to begin using the Messaging Service.

section.title: Install the Application Lifecycle Service (ALS)
section.p: This section provides details on installing the Application Lifecycle service from the Development Platform.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: For ALS to install dependencies for deployed applications, you must provide ALS with outbound Internet connectivity. This process is documented in Step 7 of "Starting the seed and building your cloud" in the baremetal installation instructions. If an HTTP Proxy is required for Internet downloads, follow the instructions in the ALS Administration Guide.

ol.li: Open Horizon and login as the "Admin" user. Then click on the Admin panel in Horizon and select Development Platform. Finally, click on Configure Services.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services panel and enter your username and password for the HPE Download Network (HPN). Select the Sign-up button if you do not have an account.

section.title: Download and Configure the Application Lifecycle Service

ol.li: In the Configure Services panel, locate the Application Lifecycle Service item in the Configure Services table.

Select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.
Downloading multiple services simultaneously is not supported, and will leave the server in an error state.
Once the download is complete, click the Configure Service button to configure the Application Lifecycle Service and wait for the configuration step to complete.

Log out from the Horizon dashboard. Log back into the Horizon dashboard as a non-admin user and click on the Application Lifecycle Service panel under the current Project to being using Application Lifecycle Services.

section.title: Install the Database Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the Database Service from the Development Platform.

section.title: Availability Zones
section.p: To configure the Database Service in a highly available manner, it is necessary to create separate availability zones. As a best practice, HPE recommends creating three availability zones. All compute hosts should be placed within one of these availability zones. If a compute host is not associated with an availability zone, the Database Service will not be able to provision a database instance to it. As a result, the Database Service may run out of capacity even though there are compute hosts with free capacity.
The following steps show how to create three availability zones and assign a compute host to the zone.

ol.li: Connect to an overcloud controller node and execute the following commands to create three availability zones named: "AZ-1", "AZ-2" and "AZ-3".nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-1 AZ-1 nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-2 AZ-2 nova aggregate-create aggregate-AZ-3 AZ-3
Validate that the availability zones were correctly created by issuing the following command.nova aggregate-list

The following commands will add a compute host to your newly created availability zones. Issue this command for every compute host that you wish to associate with an availability zone.nova aggregate-add-host <id> <hostname>
The following command can be used to list all availability zones and the compute hosts associated with them.nova availability-zone-list

section.title: Quotas
section.p: The Database Service will be installed into the admin tenant of the HPE Helion OpenStack overcloud and the admin tenant must have sufficient quota available and unused resources for the service to use. To check existing quota availability, log-in to Horizon as the admin user and open the Overview panel under the Compute tab.

In addition to the quota mentioned above, for every database instance that is created by a user, the necessary resources to create that instance will be deducted from the admin tenant quota. The users database service quota will also be affected.

ol.li: Open Horizon and log in as the "admin" user. Then click on the admin panel in Horizon and select the Development Platform panel under Admin. Then click on the Configure Services sub-panel.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services panel and enter your username and password for the HPE Download Network (HPN). Select the Sign-up button if you do not have an account.

In the Configure Services panel locate the Database Service item in the Configure Services table and select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.
Downloading multiple services simultaneously is not supported, and will leave the server in an error state.

section.title: Configuring the Database Service

ol.li:
Once the download is complete, click the Configure Service button to begin configuration of the service. In the configuration dialog, specify the following configuration options:
Service User Password (Required) - The password for the Admin user that is currently logged in. This password MUST match the password used to log in to Horizon.
Key Pair (Required) - Key Pair to install on all instances created as part of the database service. The public key can be used by an admin to get SSH access to all instances.
External Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has external network access. For HPE Helion OpenStack Commercial Edition this network is named ext-net .
Provider Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has network access to cloud infrastructure services. For HPE Helion OpenStack Commercial Edition this network is named SVC.
NTP Server IP - IP Address to an NTP server to use if instances will not have outbound access to the internet.
Logstash RabbitMQ IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of the RabbitMQ Server publishing to the central Logstash server.
Logstash RabbitMQ Password (Required) - Specify the password for the RabbitMQ Server publishing to the central Logstash server.
Ephemeral CA Password (Required) - Specify the password for the Ephemeral CA server.
Ephemeral CA IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of Ephemeral CA server.
Volume Type (Required) - The volume type to use when creating database instances.
Enable HA - Specify if the database service is to be set up in a high-availability (HA) configuration. If selected, each component of the service will have three instances created and active at all times.
After all configuration options have been provided, select the Configure button to complete the configuration step. Wait for the configuration step to complete and the status to change to Configured.

section.sectiondiv:
Configure HAProxyThe following steps will configure HAProxy to receive and forward HTTP requests to the VM that hosts the REST API endpoint for the Database Service.To perform these steps you must be connected to the overcloud.
Identify the API server IPs on the SVC network. You should have as many API servers (and IPs) as you have Availability Zones in your HPE Helion OpenStack installation.nova list | awk '/trove[0-9]*_api/{ print $4,"\t", substr($12,5) }'
Identify the Virtual IP used by the controller nodes to be able to load balance the Helion OpenStack services:keystone endpoint-list | awk '/8779/{ print $6 }' | egrep -o "[0-9]+.[0-9]+.[0-9]+.[0-9]+"
Update configuration on each of the HPE Helion OpenStack controller nodes by connecting to the controller and doing the following:
Edit the /etc/haproxy/manual/paas.cfg file and add the following lines. The last line should be repeated once for each API server identified in step 1.listen trove_api bind <Virtual IP from step 2>:8779 option httpchk GET / server trove-trove<n>_api-<uniqueid> <API server n's IP Address> check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5 check-ssl ca-file /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
Edit the /etc/iptables/rules.v4 file and add to it:-I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT
Run the following command as root:sudo iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT
Reload the haproxy service configurationsudo service haproxy reload
Log out from the Horizon dashboard. Log back into the Horizon dashboard as a non-admin user and click on the Database panel under the current Project to being using Database Service.

section.title: Install the Marketplace Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the Marketplace service from the Development Platform.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: The Marketplace Service will be installed into the admin tenant of the HPE Helion OpenStack overcloud. The admin tenant must have sufficient quota available and unused for the resources the service uses. To check existing quota availability, log in to Horizon as the admin user and open the Overview panel under the Compute tab.

section.title: Ports
section.p: If both the Marketplace and the Database Service are running on a single tenant, the default quota limit for Ports (50) is insufficient and the installation will not complete.

ol.li: Open Horizon and log in as the "admin" user. Then click on the admin panel in Horizon and select the Development Platform Panel under Admin. Then click on the Configure Services sub-panel.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services panel and enter your username and password for the HPE Download Network (HDN). Select the Sign-up button if you do not have an account.

In the Configure Services panel, in the Configure Services table, locate the Marketplace Service item. Select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.
Downloading multiple services simultaneously is not supported, and will leave the server in an error state.

section.title: Configuring the Marketplace Service

ol.li:
Once the download is complete, click the Configure Service button to begin configuration of the service. In the configuration dialog, specify the following configuration options:
Service User Password (Required) - The password for the Admin user that is currently logged in. This password MUST match the password used to log in to Horizon.
Key Pair (Required) - Key Pair to install on all instances created as part of the database service. The public key can be used by an admin to get SSH access to all instances.
External Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has external network access. For HPE Helion OpenStack Commercial Edition this network is named 'ext-net'
Provider Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has network access to cloud infrastructure services. For HPE Helion OpenStack Commercial Edition this network is named 'SVC'
NTP Server IP - IP Address to an NTP server to use if instances will not have outbound access to the internet.
Logstash RabbitMQ IP Address (Required) - This is the undercloud IP address.
Logstash RabbitMQ Password (Required) - This is the undercloud RabbitMQ password.
Ephemeral CA Password (Required) - Specify the password for the Ephemeral CA server.
Ephemeral CA IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of Ephemeral CA server.
Subnet range (Required) - The subnet to use for Marketplace.
Do not attempt to install any Marketplace packages yet. Log out from the Horizon console.

The following steps will configure HAProxy to receive and forward HTTP requests to the VM that hosts the REST API endpoint for Marketplace. To perform these steps you must be connected to the overcloud node.
Identify the API server IP on the SVC network. For the Marketplace service, there is only one API server.nova list | awk '/marketplace-api/{ print $14 }' | cut -d "=" -f 2
Identify the Virtual IP used by the controller nodes to be able to load balance the Helion OpenStack services:keystone endpoint-list | awk '/8082/{ print $6}' | grep -Eo '([0-9]*\.){3}[0-9]*'
Update configuration on each of the HPE Helion OpenStack controller nodes. For EACH node:
Connect to the controller.
Open the /etc/haproxy/manual/paas.cfg file and add the following lines. listen marketplace_api bind <Virtual IP from step 2>:8082 option httpchk GET / server marketplace<n>_api-<uniqueid> <API server n's IP Address> check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5 check-ssl ca-file /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
Open the /etc/iptables/iptables file and add this line before the COMMIT line in the file:-I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8082 -j ACCEPT
Run the following command as root:sudo iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8082 -j ACCEPT
Reload the haproxy service configuration.sudo service haproxy reload

Download the Vertica package.
Open Horizon and log in as the "admin" user. Then click on the admin panel in Horizon and select the Development Platform Panel under Admin. Then click on the Configure Services sub-panel.
Select the "Vertica Trial Package for Marketplace".
Select Download Service and confirm the download.
Wait for the service to finish downloading.
Downloading multiple services simultaneously is not supported, and will leave the server in an error state.
Log back into the Horizon console as a non-admin user. Click on the Marketplace panel under the current Project to begin using the Marketplace Service. You may now install Marketplace packages.

section.p: Your installation is now complete. If you encounter problems, refer to the Troubleshooting documentation.
